title: F is a mixture of two inorganic salts. Carry out the following exercises on F. Record your observations and identify any gas(es) evolved. State the conclusions you draw from the result of each test.
body:
(a) Put all of F in a beaker and add about 10cm³ of distilled water. Stir well and filter. Keep the filtrate and the residue.
(b)(i) To about 2cm³ of the filtrate, add NaOH<sub>(aq)</sub> in drops and then in excess.
(ii) To another 2cm³ portion of the solution, add a few drops of NH3<sub>(aq)</sub> in drops and then in excess.
(c) To about 2cm³ of the solution, add a few drops of HNO<sub>3(aq)</sub> followed by a few drops of AgNO<sub>3(aq)</sub>.
(d)(i) Put all the residue into a clean test-tube and add HNO<sub>3(aq)</sub>.
(ii) To a portion of the solution from (d)(i), add NaOH<sub>(aq)</sub> in drops and then in excess.
subject: Chemistry

title: A is 0.200 mol/dm³ of HCI.C is a solution containing 14.3g of Na₂CO₃.xH₂O in 500 cm³ of solution.
body:
a) Put A into the burette and titrate it against 20.0cm³ or 25.0cm³ portions of C using methyl orange as an indicator. Repeat the titration to obtain consistent titre values. Tabulate your results and calculate the average volume of A used. The equation for the reaction is: Na₂CO₃·xH₂O + 2HCl<sub>(aq)</sub> → 2NaCl<sub>(aq)</sub> + CO<sub>2(g)</sub> + (x + 1<sub>3</sub>)H₂O<sub>l</sub>
(b) From your results and the information provided, calculate the:
(i) concentration of C in moldm<sup>-3</sup>.
(ii) concentration of C in gdm<sup>-3</sup>.
(iii) molar mass of Na₂CO₃·xH₂O.
(iv) the value of x in Na₂CO₃·xH₂O. [H = 1.0; C = 12.0; O = 16.0; Na = 23.0]
subject: Chemistry
